texts.shortText: Large, tall, bushy species attached by a crustose holdfast and with elongate segments separated by very distinct and wide (1-2 mm) black joints. Segments cylindrical and fairly uniform in width, slightly flattened. Branches regularly, the ends of branches rounded and white. Surfaces of segments distinctively covered with warty reproductive structures. Colour purplish-pink.
Colonies can be up to 300 mm tall, but more typically 150 mm. Segments up to 7 mm long and 1-2 mm wide.

Global: Gambia in West Africa, South Africa, Madagascar, Tanzania and several other Indo-Pacific localities, including Australia (type-locality).

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.
Common and abundant on south and east coast, where can form large hanging clumps in lowshore pools and on subtidal rocks.
Hemispherical structures containing reproductive organs form conspicuous bumps on segments.

Easy to identify to genus due to elongate segments with prominent reproductive conceptacles on surface. The smaller A. capensis (typically 50-100 mm) also occurs in the SW Cape, but in this species the black joints are largely concealed by apron-like extensions on the ends of the segments.

Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.
